p: Different studies have attributed susceptibility to HRV infection to impaired IFN-I production that leads to a higher viral load [ 127, 128]. Abnormal HRV-induced IFN in asthmatic patients was shown in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) for IFN- α and in primary human bronchial epithelial cells for IFN- β [ 129]. In addition, in vitro studies on epithelial cells showed that exogenous IFN-I led to reduced viral load [ 130]. Furthermore, this has been confirmed in epithelial cells from asthmatic patients, suggesting a role for IFN-I in limiting induced viral exacerbations [ 131]. However, other groups have found no differences between viral loads in asthmatic and control subjects during HRV infections [ 132]. Further investigation regarding the role of IFN-I during HRV infections needs to be completed.
